oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: U.P.W.A Song Sheet Sheet Music
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: An original, two-page typed song sheet packet for the U.P.W.A.

The United Packinghouse Workers of America, or UPWA, was America's union of meatpackers. Founded as the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen in 1897, the meat industry union fought for labor rights in the notoriously harsh conditions highlighted in Upton Sinclair's The Jungle. By 1937 the Packinghouse Workers Organizing Committee took over as the premier meat packing union, after a number of failed strikes by the AMCBW. In 1943, the PWOC changed its name to the United Packinghouse Workers of America, and in the 1940s and 1950s fought for equal rights for its African American and women members. The UPWA lost its power after the meat packing industry changed following World War II.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: United Packinghouse Workers of America; Folk music; Highlander Folk School (Monteagle, Tenn.); Working class--Education; Working class--Songs and music; Labor movement; Labor movement--United States--History
